I am the wife of Frederick Phillipson, a night watchman, of 7, Milton House, John Street, Old Kent Road—the house is let out in floors—the prisoner lived there with her husband two floors above me—I went to live there about three months ago—the prisoner had been there about three weeks before—her lass child was about three weeks old—when I first saw it it was a clean, husband child—I think there were four children—I never saw the husband till the night the baby died; he was away all day—I saw the prisoner's sister there for some time after the child was born—she left about four or five weeks ago—I did not see the child for three weeks after that; I then saw a great difference in it—it was very dirty and neglected—that was only a week before its death—it looked as if it was being literally starved to death—it was very emaciated and thin and not clean as a baby should be kept—when I first saw it was very nice and clean, very small, but very plump—when I saw it a week before its death it was in its mother's arms—she asked me what I thought of it—I said I thought it was very ill and neglected—she said she was going tÃ³ a doctor's—I saw her when she returned—she said she had been to the doctor's, and he told her not to feed the baby, that the breast would be sufficient—I told her I thought she was seldom at home to feed the baby or suckle it either—she told me to mind my own business—I asked her once or twice afterwards how the baby was, and she said it was a little better—I was never inside her room till the baby died—I have met the prisoner out in the street or on the stairs at times, and I have seen her at the Bricklayers' Arms, and I have asked her two or three times to come home to the children—I went there to look for her because the children were crying—I went there for her three or four times just lately before the baby's death—the children were some
times in the room; the elder one could reach the latch of the door and get out, and leave the two little ones in—when I saw the prisoner at the public-house she was under the influence of drink—I seldom saw her sober till I saw her in Court—she would stand on the stairs and say she had a husband that could allow her 1l. 15l. a week; she told that to all in the house, not only to me—it was on 23rd October that I saw the child dead—I was standing outside the door, and I heard some one say "Good God, the baby is dead"—the husband asked me to come inside, and I went in, and saw the baby dead on the bed—that was about a quarter to 11 at night—I had seen the prisoner come home that evening a little after 7;, she had gone out about 11—when I went into the room the child was dirty and the bed was dirty—it had on a little calico nightgown, no flannel or anything else—the prisoner only said what a bad job it was the baby was dead—I asked her if she had anything I could lay it out in—she said "No," and we borrowed a sheet to lay it out in—I asked the husband to fetch a doctor, and he went and fetched hÃ­m—I don't think the prisoner said anything to him except asking him for a certificate, and after he had seen the baby he said he could not give one—the husband said he wanted a post-mortem examination and an inquiry to show the cause of the child's death—I told him to look at his wife and see the condition she was in—she was under the influence of drink then—I believe the husband to be a hard-working, industrious man, indulgent to a fault to her.
Cross-examined. I had the child in my arms when I first saw it; it

was then a perfectly sound child, and a pretty baby too—its arms and legs were not blue—it was healthy; it had nothing the matter with it—I am a mother—all a child of three months requires is the breast—I never saw the prisoner out with the child—I know it was continually crying while she was out.
Re-examined. I never saw her give it the breast.

MARY BURKE . I am the wife of Patrick Burke, and live on the floor above the prisoner—I was in the house when the baby was born—I first saw it about a month afterwards—it then appeared to be healthy; it was thin—I saw the sister in the house: I can't tell when she left—shortly before the child died I met the prisoner on the stairs, and said "You are neglecting your baby;" she said "Mind your own business"—I think she had the child with her at that time—I never went into her room—I have met her in the passage—sometimes I have seen her going into a public-house or coming from it—I have seen her under the influence of drink since this child was born.

MARTHA PEPPER . I live in the same house with my children—I know the prisoner—I only saw the baby once; that was a week before it died—it was in her arms rolled in a shawl in the street, going away from home—I did not say anything to her—I never spoke to her till the night after the bady died—she called a little girl I had the care of a b—bitch, and she called me everything—she said she had a man to keep her at 1l. 15s. a week; I said "Moreshame for you"—I had heard the baby crying the whole of the day—I never heard it crying before—I have seen the prisoner a number of times, sometimes sober and some
times not.
Cross-examined. I occupied the top floor—the prisoner lived two floors below—it was in passing downstairs that I heard the child crying.

MARY PERKINS . I saw the baby a few times before it died—it was a very small baby born—I did not see it again until the day of its death—I have seen the prisoner once or twice under the influence of drink—I have heard the children crying for food on one or two occasions, and have given them food.
Cross-examined. I saw the baby about an hour after it was born—it was plump, but very small—I never saw any blueness about it—I did not notice it particularly.

JAMES INGLIS MASON . I am a surgeon at 15, The paragon, New Kent Road—on 17th October a child named Hudson was brought to me for advice by two women, I believe the prisoner to be one of them—I observed its smallness, thinness, and its shrivelled condition, and a slightly blue or veinous look about the extremities, the arms and legs—I gave a prescription, a slight stimulant—I don't remember the directions I gave about its food—on 24th October, in the morning, two women came again—I sent them away and asked them to send the mother, and in the evening the prisoner came with another woman—she told me about the child being dead, and wanted to know if I could certify as to the cause of death—I gave a certificate that it died of cyanosis, that is simply a defect in the circulation—I told them on the 17th that I thought the child would die—improper nourishment or want of sufficient nourishment would cause much the same appearance that I saw on the 17th—if the heart was in a healthy condition I should ascribe the appearance I saw to defective nutrition.

Cross-examined. It is far better for a young child to be fed from the breast—you might have similar appearances to those I saw from simple weakness—children often suffer under the treatment of artificial food, and they occasionally refuse to take it—I should expect a long series of artificial food to cause the same appearances that I saw.

HENRY DARCY POWER . I am a licentiate of the College of Surgeons, 66, Old Kent Road—I was called by the prisoner's husband on the night of 23rd October to see the dead body of the child—it was very greatly emaciated—he said he wished a post-mortem—the subject of a certificate was broached by him or the prisoner, I could not say which, and I declined to give one.

FREDERICK HALL . I am foreman to Mr. Burridge, an undertaker, of 72, Southwark Bridge Road—on 26th October I fetched the body of a child from No. 4, Milton House—it was then in a blue coffin—I took it to the mortuary at St. George's in the Borough, and left it there—there was no other body of a child there.
WILLIAM THOMAS . I am the mortuary keeper of St George's—on the morning of 27th October I found the body of a child there, which had been brought by Hall—it was in a blue coffin.

ROBERT GIBSON BROWN . I am a surgeon, of 144, Brixton Road—by direction of the Coroner I made a post-mortem examination of the body of a child at the mortuary of St. George's on 27th October—it was a child about three months old, in a blue coffin—there were no marks of violence on the body—it was very emaciated, there was a total absence of fat—all the organs were perfectly healthy—the stomach had a small quantity of milk in it, but the intestines were quite empty—it was very thin indeed, almost transparent—the omentum had no fat in it—it weighed 5 lb., it ought to have weighed 11 lb. or 12 lb.—I ascribed the death to starvation, there was nothing else to account for it—there was nothing in the condition of the heart to suggest cyanosis as the cause of death—extreme debility might simulate it—if the child had had improper food there would have been irritation in the intestines, and there was none.
Cross-examined. If improper food had been administered before the 17th and not subsequently I should not expect to find irritation of the intestines.
By the COURT. The child died from want of nourishment; what I saw indicated that there had been no food at all, proper or improper.

CATHERINE NEVIN . I am the wife of a porter in the Old Kent Road—I have known the prisoner a short time—I went with her with the child to Dr. Mason—he asked her what she fed it on—she said on nursery biscuits and corn flour—he asked if she gave it the breast—she said she did—he said he thought the breast sufficient for it; that was all.
Cross-examined. I had known her between five and six months—the baby was a day old when I first saw it—I have, seen her suckle it once or twice and give it corn flour in a bottle.

THOMAS PICKLES (Police Sergeant M). On 31st October, about 7 o'clock in the morning, I took the prisoner into custody, and at the same time I took the husband; they were together in their room—I told them they would be charged with causing the death of their child by neglecting and starving it—the prisoner said "Good God! I never illtreated it; nobody

can say I ever illtreated it; God above knows I have not"—the husband said "Good God! I am out all day and do the best I can for my family, and now for this woman to bring me to this; if I gave her a pound to-night it would be all gone before the morning; I am obliged to give her money every morning before I leave; about three weeks ago I clothed the children, and now the things are all pledged; I wanted her to take the child to a doctor before, but it was no use; but at last I compelled her to take it to Dr. Mason; no one knows the trouble I have had with her"—she heard all this—I did not hear her make any remark—as they were coming out of the room he turned and said to her "Have you spent all the money I gave you yesterday?"—she felt in her pocket, but made no remark, nor did she take any money out—he then gave a young woman who was there some money and said "I must leave something for the children"—he was let out on his own recognisance to appear that day week and was then discharged by the Magistrate.

101.
JACK RANGER (37)
, B—st—y. MR. DE MICHELE Prosecuted; MR. GEOGHEGAN Defended.
NOT GUILTY .

102.
GEORGE WARD (21)
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin,
also to having it in his possession with intent to utter it.—
Fifteen Months Hard Labour.

103.
WALTER WILSON (20)
to unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin, and to having it in his possession with intent to utter it.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour. And
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

104.
JOSEPH MYCROFT (19) and
WILLIAM RICHARDS (20)
to robbery with violence on
William Pennett and stealing from him a watch and chain and 18s. 6d., his goods and money. MYCROFT** also PLEADED GUILTY to a previous conviction in July, 1878; and RICHARDS* to one in April, 1881. MYCROFT—
Five Years' Penal Servitude and
Twenty Strokes with the Cat.
RICHARDS—
Five Year's Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 10.
